sub_title: Senior Scientist @ PathoFinder B.V. | Infectious Disease Diagnosis
summary:
As a Senior Scientist at PathoFinder, a leading company in molecular diagnostics, I apply my PhD in Bioengineering and my expertise in stem cells, CRISPR/Cas gene editing, and regenerative medicine to develop new products for the diagnosis of infectious diseases.

With over 8 years of experience in academic and industry research, I have contributed to multiple projects that aim to improve human health and well-being, such as creating iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes for genetic testing, generating reporter stem cell lines for tissue engineering, and screening and validating diagnostic assays. I also provide support for marketing, business, and sales, assist with quality assurance and management systems, and train and supervise project teams. My mission is to use my scientific background and skills to create innovative solutions that can benefit patients and healthcare providers.

authors.headline: Senior Scientist @ PathoFinder B.V. | Infectious Disease Diagnosis

profile_positions.description: Development of new 2SMART products for the diagnosis of infectious diseases, providing support for marketing, business and sales, assisting with Quality Assurance and Quality Management Systems, training and supervising project teams.
profile_positions.title: Senior Scientist

profile_positions.description: In the lab of prof Jan Glatz and prof Han Brunner, I am working on the generation of iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes from patients with dilated cardiomyopathy into a functional model for testing pathogenicity of genetic variants. The research project is to ultimately develop diagnostic tools and therapies for patients with genetic DCM, by using CRISPR-Cas9 technology.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: My role in this position was to generate reporter human pluripotent stem cell lines for mesodermal lineages, specifically for bone, muscle, cartilage and fat tissues. I was heavily involved in the screening and validation of these reporter constructs in multiple cell lines. These reporter systems would be further utilised in high throughput screening for their differentiation potential in synthesised hydrogel systems. Another side project was to encapsulate these reporter cell lines in bioprinted, multilayered constructs to fabricate a tissue mimic for tissue engineering applications.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist

company.name: Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology AIBN

profile_positions.company: Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology AIBN
profile_positions.description:
Nanoparticle-based in vivo direct cardiac reprogramming using triple transgenic mouse models

In this role, I was heavily involved in targeted gene delivery for in vitro and in vivo direct/iPS reprogramming using our non-viral polymer nanoparticle systems. The next step was to utilise the multicomponent delivery system for in vivo gene delivery and cardiac reprogramming in triple transgenic mice. Cardiac surgeries on MI-induced mouse models were performed as well as end point analysis such as histological processing of heart tissues, immunohistochemical and immunofluorescent staining or flow cytometry
profile_positions.title: Research Officer

profile_positions.company: Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology AIBN
profile_positions.description:
Thesis: A self-assembling, targeted biomaterial delivery system for cardiac regeneration

 I was involved in the design and development of a non-viral vector for gene therapy, specifically for cardiac reprogramming. The skill set and expertise that I have developed during my PhD range from polymer synthesis and characterisation, hydrogel fabrication, isolation of primary cardiac fibroblasts, cell culture and maintenance of cardiac fibroblasts, vector cloning, plasmid extractions, molecular biology, lentiviral transductions, non-viral transfections of plasmids and miRNAs, direct cardiac reprogramming using nanoparticles, intramyocardial injections, cardiac surgery, animal handling and dissections using murine models.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description: My role was to facilitate the Business Development Manager with administrative tasks such as organising user records (initial contact forms, risk assessments, rsvp lists), asset number updates, adding users into the system and stationery orders. I also assisted the Business Development Manager and Facility Manager with processing and management of the ANFF-Q client database, mailing list updates, memberships, monthly and annual usage statements
profile_positions.title: Administrative Assistant

profile_positions.description: I was responsible for preparing and tutoring course material to a small and large group of students. I also assisted the lecturer and course coordinator with the marking scheme of quizzes, thesis and  final exams.  I was in charge of organising lab practicals and teaching material for the students as well as supervised and mentored the students by teaching them techniques and skills required for the practical course
profile_positions.title: CHEE4034 Cell and Tissue Engineering Tutor

company.name: Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology AIBN

profile_positions.company: Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology AIBN
profile_positions.description: In this role, I was responsible for assisting the laboratory manager to manage the operations of the lab, budgeting and keeping stocks up to date. I was also involved in multiple projects, which involved the isolation, culture and maintenance of bone marrow and placental-derived MSCs for cartilage tissue engineering, cell characterisation, in vitro 3D cell culture of MSCs, trilineage differentiation and end-point analyses. Additionally, I was in charge of supervising PhD students with their research and had my own research project to meet research grant outcomes.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: During my final year honours research project, I fabricated polyacrylamide gels of varying stiffnesses, optimised surface chemistry of polyacrylamide gel surfaces for protein conjugation, conducted cell culture of 3T3 fibroblasts and mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs), performed compression testing (using Instron Mechanical Analyser) on polyacrylamide gels and presented my work, Biocellular Research Project at the University of Melbourne Endeavour Exhibition
profile_positions.title: Final Year Honours Research Project

profile_positions.description: I was working as a research assistant to assist a PhD student with his research project on cardiac tissue engineering. I was involved in animal dissections to obtain rat hearts for cell isolation and cell culture of neonatal rat cardiomyocytes, cell maintenance of adipose derived stem cells, and 3T3 fibroblasts. I also conducted experiments with ECM protein coating on hydrogel surfaces as well as assisted in construction of hydrogels with encapsulated cells using a stereolithography system.I also performed fluorescent staining using phalloidin. My research project was presented in Undergraduate Research Workshop 2009 at Engineers Australia.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

volunteer_experiences.description: I participated in the Ride to Conquer Cancer where all riders had to fundraise a minimum of $2,500 and ride 200km over 2 days. I've managed to raise $3,000, which will all go towards funding cancer research at QIMR.

company.name: Santos GLNG Brisbane to Gold Coast

volunteer_experiences.description: Donated to the Heart Foundation and rode 100km from Brisbane to Gold Coast. This event was held to raise awareness for heart disease and to fundraise for the Heart Foundation.
I was heavily involved in managing the event, making sure the location was well set up to accommodate the number of people attending and also helping the speakers with their presentations.
Cycled 60km with Clinical Genetics team of MUMC and RadboudMC to raise funds for Slowcare Elzeneindhuis, a charity organisation for people with disabilities.
I’m currently volunteering at VHTO women in science and technology to educate young high school girls about science and biotechnology.
The Cardiac Metabolism team at Maastricht University were raising funds for the Dutch Heart Foundation by doing a cake bake sale and participating in the 11km walking event.
I'm volunteering as a Melbourne Uni alumni mentor to help young graduates with career advice, mentoring, CV development and helping them to harness their strengths for their job search.
I have been involved in managing and leading the Maastricht GGI community, helping and supporting expat women from all over the world to get settled in this beautiful city at the south of Limburg.
